questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of redness in the left eye. She says that there was no recent trauma. Her vision has not been affected, and she does not have eye pain or a foreign body sensation. There is no personal history of serious illness. Her father was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis a few years ago. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg. Ocular examination shows the findings seen in the photograph. Her visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; ocular movements are not restricted. The optic fundi are normal. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical moxifloxacin (i.e., fluoroquinolone) therapy is the appropriate treatment for pseudomonas keratitis. This condition typically affects contact lens wearers, is characterized by a fulminant course, and manifests with erythema of the entire conjunctiva and sclera, not with a focal and well-demarcated red conjunctival area like the one seen in this patient. Moreover, patients usually present with purulent discharge, foreign body sensation, photophobia, and/or pain, none of which are seen here.
Image Description:

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.

These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.

B) CORRECT:

In the case of spontaneous, nonbullous subconjunctival hemorrhage (SCH) without other symptoms (e.g., changes in visual acuity, photophobia, eye pain, foreign body sensation), no further diagnostic workup or treatment is needed. Spontaneous SCH typically occurs as a result of maneuvers that increase venous pressure in the eyeball (e.g., coughing, straining, heavy lifting, vomiting, Valsalva maneuver). Patients should be reassured that this condition, although sometimes appearing dramatic, resolves spontaneously when the blood is reabsorbed (usually within 2–3 weeks). The patient should be told that the area of hemorrhage may increase during the first days after SCH as a result of the redistribution of blood in the loculated subconjunctival space.

In the case of SCH associated with trauma, bullous SCH, or one of the aforementioned symptoms, further ophthalmologic workup is indicated, such as slit lamp examination to rule out conditions of the anterior eye (e.g., conjunctival lacerations, foreign bodies) and/or CT scan to rule out intraocular or intraorbital injury (e.g., globe rupture). Patients with recurrent spontaneous SCH should be evaluated for underlying conditions (e.g., poorly controlled hypertension, coagulopathies) and patients on an anticoagulation regimen should be evaluated for overmedication. SCH in young children can be a sign of child abuse.
Image Description:

Photograph of a patient's left eye showing subconjunctival hemorrhage.

Top (one week after hemorrhage): large, sharply demarcated areas of the sclera are red, indicating recent subconjunctival hemorrhage.

Bottom (four weeks after hemorrhage): while the lateral sclera is still red, the medial sclera has become yellow, indicating reabsorption of the blood and resolution of the hemorrhage.

Usually, subconjunctival hemorrhage resolves spontaneously within 2–3 weeks, with the color changing from red to shades of orange and yellow before clearing completely. Persistent or recurrent hemorrhage requires further investigation.

C) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the orbit must be performed in patients with subconjunctival hemorrhage (SCH) who present with a history of blunt trauma and associated symptoms (e.g., diplopia) in order to exclude intraocular and/or intraorbital injury (e.g., globe rupture, orbital fractures, retrobulbar hemorrhage). This patient, however, has spontaneous SCH with no history of blunt trauma.
Image Description:

A lower eyelid hematoma on the right side is visible. Subconjunctival bleeding is present temporally as well.

A traumatic cause was reported (fist to the eye), further investigation regarding orbital floor fracture is needed, especially as the patient reports binocular diplopia while looking upwards (not shown), suggesting an infringement of the inferior rectus muscle.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical prednisolone therapy may be used for short-term treatment of allergic conjunctivitis (AC) in patients refractory to other treatment options (e.g., antihistamines). AC manifests with bilateral conjunctival erythema, itching, and/or epiphora, not painless, unilateral, well-demarcated conjunctival redness.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Slit lamp examination should be performed in patients with symptomatic subconjunctival hemorrhage (SCH) to exclude underlying conditions of the anterior eye (e.g., conjunctival and scleral lacerations, keratoconjunctivitis, corneal abrasions, foreign bodies, anterior uveitis). Manifestations of these conditions include eye pain, foreign body sensation, and/or photophobia. This patient, however, has spontaneous SCH with no other symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Measurement of blood clotting indices is indicated in patients with recurrent subconjunctival hemorrhage (SCH) and in patients with other signs of bleeding diathesis (e.g., petechiae, epistaxis) to evaluate for an underlying bleeding disorder. In addition, coagulation studies should be obtained in patients with SCH who are on an anticoagulation regimen to rule out overmedication. This otherwise healthy patient, however, has spontaneous SCH with no other symptoms.
questions.hint: The photograph shows a focal, well-demarcated, conjunctival erythema, which is consistent with a subconjunctival hemorrhage (SCH).

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of foreign body sensation in his eyes. During this time, he has felt like there is sand in his eyes, and this sensation has slowly increased. He has no recent trauma and does not have eye pain or redness. He reports that he sometimes has difficulty looking at objects on the far temporal sides. He works for the postal service and spends most of the day outdoors delivering mail. He has hypertension that is well-controlled with enalapril. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 124/81 mm Hg. Ocular examination shows the findings in the photograph. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The optic fundi are normal. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to wearing sunglasses, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are an appropriate treatment for bacterial conjunctivitis, which manifests with foreign body sensation. Unlike a pterygium, bacterial conjunctivitis usually manifests with generalized erythematous conjunctiva and purulent discharge and does not restrict ocular motility.

B) INCORRECT:

Laser photocoagulation is used to treat ocular conditions associated with neovascularization (e.g., diabetic retinopathy, branch retinal vein occlusion) by minimizing the growth of new vessels. Although neovascularization is a mechanism in the pathophysiology of pterygium, laser photocoagulation is not recommended as an initial treatment and is only used as adjuvant therapy for recurrent pterygium.

C) CORRECT:

Surgical excision is the preferred treatment for a pterygium that restricts ocular motility and/or impairs visual acuity. Additional indications for surgical excision include progressive growth and persistent irritation that is resistant to conservative therapy. A small pterygium that does not require surgery can be managed with UV protection measures (e.g., wearing sunglasses and a hat) and ocular lubricants (e.g., artificial tears) to reduce foreign body sensation and chronic irritation. Recurrence after surgical removal is common and indicates a high risk of recurrence after subsequent procedures.

D) INCORRECT:

Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor therapy is used to treat ocular conditions associated with neovascularization (e.g., age-related macular degeneration, diabetic macular edema) by targeting angiogenesis. Although levels of VEGF are increased in pterygium tissue, anti-VEGF therapy is not routinely recommended because there is limited evidence that it improves symptoms or affects prognosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and artificial tears are an appropriate initial treatment for a small pterygium with local irritation and no impairment of vision and eye movement. These measures are insufficient for this patient with restricted ocular motility.

Topical lubricants are also appropriate for pinguecula, which is a conjunctival lesion with symptoms of local irritation (e.g., foreign body sensation) caused by chronic exposure to UV light. A pinguecula is a yellowish plaque that is confined to the conjunctiva and therefore does not impact ocular motility or vision.
questions.hint: This patient has a triangular, fibrovascular wedge of conjunctival tissue growing from the nasal conjunctiva towards the cornea known as pterygium, for which chronic UV radiation exposure is an important risk factor.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man reports a one-month history of foreign-body sensation in his left eye. He denies any sudden vision changes but does have occasional clear discharge from the eye. His history is significant for basal-cell carcinoma (resected from his back 10 years ago), hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and gout.
On examination, visual acuity is 20/25 in his right eye and 20/40 in his left eye. A vascular growth is noted over the conjunctiva and nasal cornea of his left eye (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis is characterized by redness, itching, foreign-body sensation, and morning crusting of the eyelids. Symptoms typically start in one eye and spread to the other within a few days.

B) INCORRECT:

A pinguecula is often confused with a pterygium. It appears as a yellowish raised lesion of the conjunctiva, but unlike the pterygium seen in this case, a pinguecula will not extend onto the corneal surface.

C) INCORRECT:

Corneal abrasions are associated with acute, intense pain and, when stained with fluorescein, appear green under a cobalt-blue light.

D) INCORRECT:

Blepharitis can cause foreign-body sensation, irritation, and tearing but not a growth on the conjunctiva or cornea.

E) CORRECT:

A pterygium is a vascular growth that usually begins medially on the conjunctiva and may extend onto the cornea. Pterygia are seen most commonly in patients who have a substantial history of exposure to ultraviolet light. They can cause foreign-body sensation and irritation, and they can lead to vision impairment by inducing astigmatism and blocking the visual axis as they migrate centrally toward the cornea. Lubrication with artificial tears can provide relief. A referral to an ophthalmologist is indicated if the lesion has recently become larger or symptomatic.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who presents with foreign-body sensation and a vascular growth over the conjunctiva and nasal cornea is pterygium.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents with a red spot on the sclera of her left eye (figure) that she first noticed yesterday after sneezing. She reports no recent trauma or eye pain. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and is taking lisinopril, simvastatin, and aspirin. She has 20/25 vision in both eyes.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A corneal ulcer is associated with ocular pain, foreign-body sensation, decreased vision, and a white infiltrate on the cornea.

B) INCORRECT:

Corneal abrasion is characterized by ocular pain, typically after trauma, and a clear cornea that stains with fluorescein dye.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis is associated with ocular injection and crusting.

D) CORRECT:

Subconjunctival hemorrhage can develop as a result of trauma, Valsalva maneuvers, or sneezing. It can also occur spontaneously; risk factors for spontaneous subconjunctival hemorrhage include coagulopathies, hypertension, and use of anticoagulants. Patients with subconjunctival hemorrhage typically have normal visual acuity and do not have any symptoms other than acute localized ocular redness.

Subconjunctival hemorrhage is self-limited and will resolve in 2 to 3 weeks. Recurrent subconjunctival hemorrhages require a slit-lamp examination to rule out associated ocular-surface disorders and an evaluation for bleeding disorders. If the subconjunctival hemorrhage develops after trauma to the eye, the patient should have a dilated-eye examination to rule out other ocular damage.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a large spot on the sclera that develops after sneezing is subconjunctival hemorrhage.

E) INCORRECT:

Scleritis is characterized by red eye, severe eye pain, and tenderness. It is associated with systemic diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener’s).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man reports a 1-month history of foreign-body sensation in his left eye. On examination, visual acuity is 20/25 in his right eye and 20/40 in his left eye. A vascular growth is noted over the conjunctiva and nasal cornea of his left eye. A photograph of the left eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

D) INCORRECT:

Lubrication with artificial tears can provide relief. A referral to an ophthalmologist is indicated if the lesion has recently become larger or symptomatic.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who presents with foreign-body sensation and a vascular growth over the conjunctiva and nasal cornea is pterygium.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 1-hour history of redness in her left eye. She reports no recent trauma, no changes in vision, and no eye pain or foreign body sensation. Ocular examination reveals the findings shown in the photograph. Her visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Pupils are equal and reactive to light, ocular movements are not restricted, and the optic fundi are normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

SCH in young children can be a sign of child abuse.

Key learning point: A painless, well-demarcated subconjunctival hemorrhage without vision changes or trauma requires only reassurance, as it resolves spontaneously within 2–3 weeks.

Photograph of a patient's left eye showing subconjunctival hemorrhage.

Top (one week after hemorrhage): large, sharply demarcated areas of the sclera are red, indicating recent subconjunctival hemorrhage.

Bottom (four weeks after hemorrhage): while the lateral sclera is still red, the medial sclera has become yellow, indicating reabsorption of the blood and resolution of the hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to your clinic because she noticed a red spot on the sclera of her left eye yesterday after sneezing. She denies recent trauma or eye pain. Her medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, and her medications are lisinopril, simvastatin, and aspirin. On examination, the findings are shown in the photograph. Her visual acuity is 20/25 in both eyes. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
